instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message:
hello friends

i just work on this board. it came in with"liquid damage" but i looked the whole board and nothing to see, its not cleaned.

i found a short <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to GND, After replacing <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> i got a fanspin, but still no cpu vcore.

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> is zero. It has to be zero? in schematics is a inverted input to see.


<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> (VR-on) is 3.3V on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, VDD and VIN is ok. 

so is <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> working? 

SCLK is no clock to see in this moment.

need some assistance please what could be the next step.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is high, you should have voltage on all coils; maybe not on CPU ones.
Do you get voltage at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

Damaged <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> probably denotes dead CPU.
This looks like hopeless project...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message: is it possible to get on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 7 a High if CPUVR-PGOOD is LOW ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message: Dead CPU RIP. <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> sent 12 volts to the CPU this is done.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message:
so if the cpu would be not dead there would be a clock on SCLK to see?

the short was in <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>, that was going hot, the cpu was not hot or warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message: <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> is the high side CPU controller. If it was shorted, it stopped turning 12.56 volts into 1.8 volts for the CPU and was sending 12.56 volts to the CPU. The CPU saw 12.6 and was instantly killed. You're wasting your time on this one sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message:
"is it possible to get on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 7 a High if CPUVR-PGOOD is LOW ?"
Yes, because pin7 should go high first, in order to enable CPU power supply.
Pin 3 goes high only after VCORE is confirmed.

Your CPU has less than 1% chance to survive; case closed, don't waste more time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not start
threads.message: ok, thank you friends for your help, so i will give it back to customer. You saved my time.
